Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Deploying VentCam as a Data Collection Base Station for the Axial Seamount SensorBot Array
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI requests funds to repurpose the VentCam seafloor camera system to act as a data receiving base station during a test of the SensorBot array at Axial Seamount on the Juan de Fuca Ridge during August of 2011. The SensorBot array is a set of optically communicating and fluorescently sensing polycarbonate spheres that measure diffuse hydrothermal fluid properties using novel fluorescent polymers developed originally for use in human health applications. The redeployment of this technology will involve a substantial rewrite of the VentCam control software, and minor changes to hardware. This project represents a low-cost opportunity to demonstrate the versatility of the VentCam, and maximize its benefit to the seafloor scientific community.

Broader Impacts:

This project will also demonstrate the versatility of the VentCam system and the potential applicability of this system to address a variety of seafloor instrumentation problems. There will be several undergraduate students joining this cruise who will work alongside scientists, engineers, and the ship?s crew to gain experience using oceanographic instrumentation and to conduct their own research. POR.DRECONTENT:
Hydrothermal flow within mid-ocean ridges is the primary mechanism by which new crust cools and by which chemicals are transferred from the oceanic crust to the water column. These flows strongly influence the physical properties of the lithosphere, the chemistry of the ocean, and the geology of the crust. Hydrothermal flow delivers the energy that supports large and diverse ecosystems living at and below the seafloor, and serves as a critical link between the geophysical, chemical, and biological components of mid-ocean ridge system. The study of these processes is essential for understanding Earth's tectonic system and life in extreme environments.


Members of the mid-ocean ridge scientific community have indicated a strong interest in the development of new instrumentation that can provide real-time information regarding a wide range of fluid properties in these systems -- instruments that can operate over long time periods, respond to seismic, magmatic or other events, and connect to seafloor cabled observatory systems which will play an important role in the future of deep sea science and exploration. New instrumentation will be required to provide the information necessary to form an integrated understanding of these dynamic systems.


This project involved a seafloor test of one such instrumentation system that is a synergistic pairing of two seafloor instruments currently under development: 1) A Sensorbot array which is a set of optically sensing and communicating spheres, being developed at Arizona State University, that can measure various properties of the fluids in which they are immersed, and 2) the VentCam which was originally developed for measuring flow rates in high-temperature vents using optical image analysis, but for this project was repurposed as a communication base station for the Sensorbot array.


In August of 2011 we successfully deployed an array of 16 Sensorbots and the VentCam base station at Axial Seamount, a submarine volcano on the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the northeast Pacific Ocean. The Sensorbots performed well, measuring several fluid properties over the course of the entire two-day test, including temperature, pH, oxygen concentration, and turbidity. Eight of the 16 Sensorbots successfully transmitted their data to the base station using an asynchronous communication protocol developed for this project. The other eight were obscured from the camera system by seafloor topographical features.


We learned that Sensorbots of this generation have communication LEDs that are capable of transmitting data over a distance of at least 70 m, in water that was sometimes clouded by material from a volcanic eruption that had occured several months prior. We learned that the VentCam, with frame rates of 50 frames per second, can collect information from all Sensorbots within its field of view without requiring any synchronization between the sensors and the camera. In all, this was a successful low-cost project that has substantially increased our understanding of distributed autonomous seafloor sensor arrays that communicate optically with a base station. Work on these types of systems will continue with the expectation that distributed autonomous sensor arrays will one day operate as part of seafloor cabled observatories and perhaps in other environments as well.
